titleStmt.title: The miser a comedy acted by His Majesties servants at the Theater Royal / written by Thomas Shadwell.
titleStmt.author: Shadwell, Thomas, 1642?-1692.

editionStmt.edition: This text is an enriched version of the TCP digital transcription A59437 of text R21941 in the English Short Title Catalog (Wing S2861A). Textual changes and metadata enrichments aim at making the text more computationally tractable, easier to read, and suitable for network-based collaborative curation by amateur and professional end users from many walks of life. The text has been tokenized and linguistically annotated with MorphAdorner. The annotation includes standard spellings that support the display of a text in a standardized format that preserves archaic forms ('loveth', 'seekest'). Textual changes aim at restoring the text the author or stationer meant to publish.

respStmt.resp: This text has not been fully proofread

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 228 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 51 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

publicationStmt.pubPlace: Evanston,IL, Notre Dame, IN, St. Louis, MO

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal . The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The miser a comedy acted by His Majesties servants at the Theater Royal / written by Thomas Shadwell.
titleStmt.author: Shadwell, Thomas, 1642?-1692.
Molière, 1622-1673. Avare.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.
The main plot is almost a translation of Molières L'Avare, but many new characters and scenes have been added. cf. "Reader," 3d prelim. leaf; Miles, Influence of Molier̀e, p. 234.

ep:epHeader.ep:title: The Miser
ep:epHeader.ep:defectRangePerGrade: The rate of 5.85 defects per 10,000 words puts this text in the B category of texts with fewer than 10 defects per 10,000 words.
